Key Match Events: Anthony Volpe hit a grand slam in the third inning to give the Yankees their first lead since Game 1.
The Yankees' bullpen held off the Dodgers after the lineup supplied a late-night scoring splurge.
The game marked the first time in the World Series that the Yankees responded when trailing by the Dodgers.
Freddie Freeman hit a two-run homer in the first inning for the Dodgers.
Yankees' second baseman Gleyber Torres hit a three-run homer in the eighth inning to provide the bullpen more room to breathe.
Dodgers reliever Daniel Hudson allowed a grand slam to Volpe, which proved decisive.
The game went into extra innings as the Dodgers opened the night in punt formation with rookie pitchers Ben Casparius and Landon Knack.
Austin Wells hit a solo shot in the sixth inning and executed a double steal with Volpe in the eighth inning.
The Yankees became only the fourth team in baseball history and the first since 1970 to avoid a sweep in the World Series when down 3-0.
Pre-Game Insights: The Yankees were down 3-0 in the series but needed to avoid a sweep.
Dodgers manager Dave Roberts discussed the importance of length from two rookie pitchers, Ben Casparius and Landon Knack.
Post-Match Reflections: Yankees manager Aaron Boone expressed excitement for the opportunity to play Game 5.
Anthony Volpe described the moment as the coolest of his young life and expressed thrill that the season was not yet over.
Dodgers manager Dave Roberts felt great about the upcoming Game 5.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Yankees became only the fourth team in baseball history to avoid a sweep in the World Series when down 3-0.
The game marked the first time in the Fall Classic that the Yankees responded when wounded by the Dodgers.
Others: The Yankees overcame a mistake on the bases by Volpe to scratch together a run in the second inning.
